title: @Bioluminescence I summon you because of map!
body:
https://twitter.com/_whren/status/1021798753571749890

_So can we expect some kind of scale for distances in the future?_

And if it's possible what can you tell us about that now? 

**My main questions are: **

* Which is the lenght of the Mother of Life river? 
* How long is it on horseback or on foot from Noxus to Demacia? In days or kilometers both are fine. 
* Also any ideas about how big are in population terms Piltover/Zaun, Demacia and Noxus? 

**Thanks! **

replies.body:
And I am summoned.  (Thanks, Maisie!)

So, if a small military force, marching, were able to take a perfectly direct route from the capital of Noxus to the capital of Demacia, in fair weather, over partially paved roads, then it'd take that small marching force approximately 127 days.  Or over 4 months.

I DO have ideas on the populations of ALL the nations, and their major cities, but I'll need to check and see if I'm allowed to share, or if we need to get those numbers approved by other teams first.

Thanks for that answer. I'll do some work with it. 

I'll wait for that possible extra info too! 

{{sticker:galio-happy}} 

Again, thanks for all. You all at Riot are doing a magnificent job of worldbuilding and we completely love it.

For reference, for your calculations.

The average Roman army marched between 20-30 miles per day.  However, the legions under Julius Caesar famously marched for 50 miles per day.  The Spartans are recorded to have marched 60 miles per day on one recorded occasion.  This is matched by the Mongols at their fastest for 60 miles per day.  But both armies averaged closer to 20-30 for the Spartans and 30-40 for the Mongols.  Medieval armies at their fastest seemed to have moved at around 30 miles per day, with their average closer to 10-20.

Since the Noxians are not shown to be a force that emphasis strict military discipline and rigorous structure like the Romans and Spartans, nor do they comprise themselves of a vast cavalry force that can change mounts throughout the day to keep up speed like the Mongols.  I'd personally place them closer to the Medieval armies movement of somewhere around 15 miles per day.  However, technically, any of the above measurements could theoretically be used by the actual Rioters for their calculations and it could seem reasonable.

That had actually been quite the point of discussion (Targon's position).  Originally with this map I had placed it in the northern continent, on the mountain range between Demacia and Noxus, but that was deemed 'too convenient' for the Crown of Stone exile punishment so it was moved (with some iteration and a lot of fixing) to its present location.  I think there was also (and I suspect, knowing you, you'll be displeased to hear) a desire for it to be more 'otherworldly' and less accessible to the comings and goings of nearby warring factions, too.

Its Kled's land duh. 
No in all seriousness it has to do with the fact that Noxus and Demacia are pretty much always at war with each other, which effectively makes that land in the middle no mans land, because no one can control it for a long enough time to own it. Everytime Noxus would try to expand into that area Demacia's scouts would pick up the scent, then they send their armies out to meet them, the mountainous region also favors Demacia's opposition of Noxus's advancement and as we kno their fights usually end up in a stale mate forcing both sides to retreat as Noxus hasn't advanced and even if Demacia DID win they have no interest in taking more territory they are isolationist and are quite happy with the fertile land they already own which is behind many mountain ranges and is easy to protect.

Besides IF Targon was in the middle it would be way to easy for anyone to reach it, and also Noxus would have to PASS Targon everytime they wanted to fight Demacia which we kno they fight often. Targon is a religious site in part of its mythos, because it so DARN hard to get to, for Noxuians, Demacian, or Freljordians to get to it, because for two of them they have to pass Noxus territory, go through Piltover, pass the unnamed barren and dangerous lands after Piltover (Probably the Kumungu Jungles) pass the desert of climb thousands of mountains along the coast and then pass the final mountain range before getting to Targon. Now THATS an epic pillgrimage worth making a huge religious fuss over, not so much crossing what could be equated to have the width of the United States with only maybe a few mountain ranges in the way. 

If it were in the middles it would be 2 close.

When the Persians and the Romans had a huge border dispute and created a buffer state, the state was not larger than either Persia or Rome.  The lands between Demacia and Noxus are much larger than Demacia itself.  Frankly, "Kled's territory" is the more logical reason.

Also, Targon is supposedly the largest mountain in the world and much bigger than Mount Everest.  Unless you're Hannibal Barca you don't march an army over the mountain.  You could just march around it, which matches the details given that the bottom of Targon is supposedly a trade post.  Trade posts by their nature are not hard to get to, otherwise there'd be no trade.  It's climbing the damn mountain that was considered the hard part.

Though I have a feeling that this will be retconned, in that it will just never be mentioned again.  Targon's story isn't about politics, trade agreements, and wars.  It's about the damn space parasites now.

Just so you have some extra data:

I used the US Civil War marching as a goalpost, as that war involved some serious marching distances, and had a mix of modern and archaic tech that I think represents a good hybrid of League's technology and civilization level. It also used paved and non-paved roads.

A normal march was a 15-mile day, and a forced march was about twice that. Assuming about 20 miles a day (a few longer-than-usual days with the occasional forced march here and there), that's 2540 miles, or 4087 kilometers. That makes the distance between Noxus and Demacia roughly equivalent to the width of the United States of America.
It may do the trick. But I think that the main problem we have here is: What would Noxus send to a war with Demacia?

Well, if we use average maths it does appear pretty small.

127 days is 3048 hours. that is our time t

The average human walking speed for adults is estimated at 4km/h this is our velocity v

Means that to get the distance in km or s, we have to rewrite the original formula of v=t/s into s=t/v, we do 3048h/4km/h which results in 762km distance.

Assuming people didn't mistype one zero...or two...then the numbers given do make the lands small, given that this is noxus and demacia's capital's respectively which are quite literally one end of the main continent to the other end.

Even if we assume your 4km/h is correct, your result is wrong - you divided instead of multiplied.  

At 3048 hours of travel, and 4 km traveled per hour it is 3048 h * 4 km/h, or 12192 km (~7600 miles).

This is several thousand km longer than the Eurasian continent, which is rather massive in my book.

Military forces, historically, had a lot of things that 'slowed them down' - making and breaking camp, sleeping, negotiating rough terrain, avoiding or otherwise dealing with dangerous animals, keeping themselves fresh for the upcoming battle, uh... certain.. um... medical issues that were rife in historical contexts... etc.

well yes, there is always the argues of secondary factors that influence the given velocity. 
the walking speed i used to calculate ignores most factors because it assumes a normal march. Is the travel assumed at average 6h per day sleep duration added and good weather and the most straight possible way, assuming there are no mountains. 

sure, if we per say make the way a little more realistic for practical examples, by adding hills, maybe a mountain, and most certainly make the way not straight, which it very likely isn't anyway, then the number of days and the distance could potentially increase. but that nonethless makes it quite a small world, the longest duration i could calculate, with your numbers given, then influenced by every possible bad luck you can think of, the travel duration still barely makes it past 220 days, assuming everyone is going by foot. there's still travel options like horserides, which massively shorten the time needed, or running certain pieces of the path.

My point is...with proper calculations done, runeterra's main continent is barely as big as Europe's central area, and if roughly guessing the size then stuffing the continent multiple times to fill that globe's defined landmass, then runeterra as a whole by landmass is roughly as big as the entirety of europe, which is roughly 1/13th of the earth's entire landmass.

There are many smaller factors for back and forth arguing, but im fairly convinced that runeterra is small. travel time calculations mostly are extended by hindrances, but as said, it influences mostly the time, but not the distance. and if the distance is properly calculated then theres barely a handful of factors that might influence the numbers defined. Such as having to walk around a mountain because boulders block a tunnel through it.

> [{quoted}](name=Eternal Torment,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=h1O2atTN,comment-id=00000003000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-25T02:18:37.658+0000)...a general and universal velocity however seems to be the more legit pick as far as mathematical laws are concerned and im sorry to say i side with those.

Why? What "small military force" in existence can travel at a constant speed for 24 hours a day for 127 days with medvieval technology? Universal velocity seems really weird in this context. :P

Even then, you messed up the math. It V=X/T then it becomes X = V*T (as you multiple both sides by t), not X=T/V.

By that calculation (which you can google for reference: distance = speed * time) your numbers get a result on nearly 12000km...which is nearly three times the other estimates in this thread, and that makes sense as you assumed a 24-hour-a-day walking time as opposed to our 8-hour walking time.

So your speed is fine, but the calculation isn't. There's just no way you could walk in a straight line at a constant speed of 4km an hour for 3000 hours and only move 760km.
